Lana | full name = Abdulaziz bin Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = King Abdullah | mother = Aida Fustuq{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} | religion = [[Wahhabi]] [[Hanbali]] [[Sunni Islam]] | native_name = عبد العزيز بن عبدالله بن عبد العزيز آل سعود | native_name_lang = ar | styles = }} '''Abdulaziz bin Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Saud''' ({{lang-ar|عبد العزيز بن عبد الله بن عبد العزيز آل سعود}}) is the [[Saudi]] deputy minister of foreign affairs, and a member of the country's [[House of Saud|royal family]]. ==Early life and education== Prince Abdulaziz was born to King Abdullah,{{cite web|title=Royal Family Directory|url=https://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176561|website=Datarabia|accessdate=15 November 2017}} in Riyadh. He is the third son of King Abdullah. Abdulaziz Bin Abdullah graduated from the [[University of Hertfordshire]] with a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science in 1986. ==Career== Abdulaziz bin Abdullah served in the [[Saudi Arabian National Guard]] for fifteen years in different positions. In 1991, he was appointed as an advisor to [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|the Crown Prince Abdullah]].{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Simon|title=After King Fahd|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PP_37_AFTERKINGFAHD.pdf|publisher=Washington Institute|accessdate=2 February 2013|format=Policy Paper|year=1994}} Specifically, he was Syrian advisor of the Crown Prince Abdullah.{{cite journal|last=Henderson|first=Simon|title=Outraged in Riyadh. Is the House of Saud dumping Obama?|journal=Foreign Policy|date=14 April 2011|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/14/outraged_in_riyadh?page=0,1|accessdate=4 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013064506/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/14/outraged_in_riyadh?page=0,1|archivedate=13 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} He was also a former state minister.{{cite web|title=Member of the council of the ministers as of November 2010 |url=http://www.saudiembassy.net/about/Biographies-of-Ministers.aspx |publisher=Royal Embassy Washington D.C. |accessdate=25 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616222323/http://www.saudiembassy.net/about/Biographies-of-Ministers.aspx |archivedate=16 June 2011 }} [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] appointed Prince Abdulaziz as deputy foreign minister on 22 July 2011.{{cite web|title=H.R.H. Prince Abdulaziz bin Abdullah bin Abdulaziz, vice minister of Foreign Affairs|url=http://www.mofa.gov.sa/sites/mofaen/aboutMinistry/SeniorOfficials/Pages/ministerVP.aspx|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs|accessdate=25 May 2012}}{{cite news|title=Abdul Aziz appointed deputy foreign minister |url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20110723105830 |accessdate=12 August 2012 |newspaper=Saudi Gazette |date=23 July 2011 |location=Jeddah |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213003815/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20110723105830 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }} During the [[Syrian civil war]], Prince Abdulaziz asked [[Turkey]] to establish "nerve centre" attempting to topple Bashar Assad.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/27/us-syria-crisis-centre-idUSBRE86Q0JM20120727|title=Secret Turkish nerve center leads aid to Syria rebels|date=27 July 2012|accessdate=27 July 2012|author=Regan Doherty Bakr Amena|work=Reuters}} The center was founded in [[Adana]] in the mid-2012. Prince Abdulaziz personally deals with [[Bashar Assad]]'s file.{{cite web|title=New Saudi spymaster marks shift in policy – Target Syria and Iran |url=http://www.phantomreport.com/new-saudi-spymaster-marks-shift-in-policy-target-syria-and-iran |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131053456/http://www.phantomreport.com/new-saudi-spymaster-marks-shift-in-policy-target-syria-and-iran |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 January 2013 |work=Phantom Report |accessdate=25 September 2012 |date=27 July 2012 }} He represented Saudi Arabia at [[16th Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement|the Non-Aligned Movement summit]] in [[Tahran]] from 30 to 31 August 2012, since Foreign Affairs Minister [[Saud bin Faisal bin Abdul-Aziz|Prince Saud]] had an operation and could not attend the meeting.{{cite news|last=Henderson|first=Simon|title=Fresh Concerns about Health of Saudi King|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=431584&MID=0&PID=0|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=Now Lebanon|date=29 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Saudi Prince Arrives in Tehran to Attend NAM Summit |url=http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9106060616 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130122205544/http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9106060616 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2012 |work=Fars News Agency |date=30 August 2012 |location=Tehran }}{{cite news|last=Naqvi|first=Saeed|title=Non Alignment 2.0|url=http://www.thefridaytimes.com/beta3/tft/article.php?issue=20120907&page=6|accessdate=5 October 2012|newspaper=The Friday Times|date=7–13 September 2012}} Prince Abdulaziz met with Iranian President [[Mahmud Ahmadinejad|Mahmud Ahmedinejad]] during his stay in Tahran. ===Business activities=== Prince Abdulaziz is owner of Tower Lane Properties, a land development firm. It is reported that the company spent $12 million on five-and-a-quarter acres of land in the [[Benedict Canyon, Los Angeles|Benedict Canyon]] in 2009, and applied for permits to build a mansion. The project, later, was reduced to 60,000-square-foot. However, more than 1,000 residents of the area signed a petition against this project, requiring an environmental review. The Prince's lawyers filled a case against this petition.{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Nick|title=Son of Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah suing Los Angeles over 'mega-mansion'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/saudiarabia/9285549/Son-of-Saudi-Arabias-King-Abdullah-suing-Los-Angeles-over-mega-mansion.html|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=23 May 2012}} Prince Abdulaziz won his lawsuit against the city of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] in late August 2012.{{cite news|last=Glick Kudler|first=Adrian|title=Saudi Prince Wins (First?) BHPO Megacompound Legal Victory|url=http://la.curbed.com/archives/2012/08/saudi_prince_wins_first_bhpo_megacompound_legal_victory.php|accessdate=31 August 2012|newspaper=LA Curbed|date=27 August 2012}} ==Other activities== Abdulaziz bin Abdullah founded [https://web.archive.org/web/20121219111324/http://www.tcf.org.sa/Dimm/TCF/Pages/Default.aspx the Centennial Fund] in July 2004 and is the chairman of the Fund.{{cite web|title=The Centennial Fund. Background |url=http://www.tcf.org.sa/Dimm/TCF/Pages/Default.aspx |publisher=The Centennial Fund |accessdate=3 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121219111324/http://www.tcf.org.sa/Dimm/TCF/Pages/Default.aspx |archivedate=19 December 2012 |df=dmy }}{{Failed verification|date=October 2016}} The Fund is a nonprofit organization with the goal of supporting the Saudi business.{{cite web|title=Centennial Fund awarding grants|url=http://www.albawaba.com/business/centennial-fund-awarding-grants|work=Albawaba|accessdate=24 May 2012|date=24 March 2005}} He is also one of the members of the [[KAUST]] Board of Trustees.{{cite web|title=About Us |url=http://www.kaust.edu.sa/about/bot/boardtrustee.html |publisher=King Abdullah University of Science and Technology |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325131904/http://www.kaust.edu.sa/about/bot/boardtrustee.html |archivedate=25 March 2012 }}{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Simon|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PolicyFocus96.pdf|title=After King Abdullah|publisher=Washington Institute |accessdate=28 July 2012|format=Policy Paper|date=August 2009}} Delano Roosevelt, who is a grandson of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], and Prince Abdulaziz jointly established the Friends of Saudi Arabia.{{cite news|last=Shaikh |first=Habib |title=Friends of Saudi Arabia is breaking new grounds in US |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/darticlen.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2008/July/middleeast_July642.xml§ion=middleeast&col= |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130128061437/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/darticlen.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2008/July/middleeast_July642.xml§ion=middleeast&col= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=25 May 2012 |newspaper=Khaleej Times |date=27 July 2008 }} This organization seeks to foster the friendly relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States. Prince Abdulaziz is also chairman of the board of trustees of [[Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz International Award for Translation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/saudi-arabia/custodian-two-holy-mosques-award-translation-celebrates-winners-germany|title=Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques Award for Translation celebrates winners in Germany|work=Arab News|date=10 October 2012|accessdate=20 October 2012}} ==Personal life== {{BLP unsourced section|date=August 2016}} Abdulaziz Bin Abdullah is married and has four children, three from his previous marriage to Abeer bint Turki bin Nasser, and just one from his present wife Nathalie Ghassan Maamary. {{Children/top}} {{Children |name= Sadine |lifespan= |notes=Child of Abeer bint Turki bin Nasser }} {{Children |name=Abdullah |lifespan= |notes=Child of Abeer bint Turki bin Nasser }} {{Children |name=Khalid |lifespan= |notes=Child of Abeer bint Turki bin Nasser }} {{Children |name=Lana |lifespan= |notes=Child of Nathalie Ghassan Maamary }} {{Children/bottom}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saud, Abdulaziz bin Abdullah bin Abdulaziz al}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Hertfordshire]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:Grandsons of Ibn Saud|Abdullah, Abdulaziz bin]]

[[William Regnery II]] (cousin) }} '''Alfred S. Regnery''' (born November 21, 1942){{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=41008|title=Ronald Reagan: Nomination of Alfred S. Regnery To Be Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2016}} is an [[United States|American]] conservative lawyer, author, and former publisher.[http://www.commonwealthclub.org/events/archive/podcast/alfred-regnery-publisher-american-spectator-author-ascendance-american-conser Alfred Regnery, Publisher, The American Spectator; Author, The Ascendance of American Conservatism], [[Commonwealth Club of California]], June 2, 2008Michael W. Chapman, [http://cnsnews.com/news/article/conservative-al-regnery-resigns-publisher-american-spectator Conservative Al Regnery Resigns as Publisher of The American Spectator], ''[[Cybercast News Service]]'', February 23, 2012Phil Brennan, [http://www.newsmax.com/US/alfred-regnery/2009/12/12/id/341517 Alfred Regnery: Buckley's Spirit Lives On] ''[[Newsmax Media]]'', 20 Mar 2008{{cite web|url=https://home.isi.org/|title=Bio|first1=|last1=Contact|first2=|last2=Privacy|first3=Terms of|last3=Use|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2016}} ==Background== Alfred S. Regnery was born on November 21, 1942, in [[Chicago]].{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=41008|title=Nomination of Alfred S. Regnery To Be Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention |publisher=The White House|date=March 7, 1983}} He is the son of [[Henry Regnery]] (1912–1996), founder of [[Regnery Publishing]], a conservative publishing house founded in 1947. Regnery graduated from [[Beloit College]] in [[Beloit, Wisconsin]] in 1965 and received a J.D. from the [[University of Wisconsin Law School]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]] in 1971. ==Career== Early in his career, Regnery served as college director of the [[Young Americans for Freedom]], as a Senate aide, and the [[Lands Division]] of the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] under President [[Ronald Reagan]]. {{cite web | first = Murray | last = Waas | title = Al Regnery's Secret Life | publisher = The New Republic | url = https://newrepublic.com/article/64596/al-regnerys-secret-life | date = 23 June 1986 | accessdate = 7 November 2016}} In 1976, Regnery ran for district attorney in Madison, Wisconsin. During that campaign, he publicized allegations to the police that his wife had been injured and forced to have sexual acts with men who had broken into their home. During investigation, police allegedly discovered a "stash of pornography" in the Regnery home. {{cite book | first = David | last = Brock | authorlink = David Brock | title = The Republican Noise Machine | publisher = Crown Publishers | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bta2kKjPzTwC| page = | date = 18 May 2004 | accessdate = 8 November 2016}} Regnery served as Legal Counsel to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senator [[Paul Laxalt]] of [[Nevada]] and to the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]. From 1981 to 1986, Regnery served as Deputy Assistant Attorney General of the Land and Natural Resources Division of the [[United States Department of Justice]]. In 1983, he was appointed by President [[Ronald Reagan]] as administrator of the [[Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention]], and he worked on the [[Meese Report]]. On May 21, 1986, Regnery resigned his position as administrator "abruptly" to return to the family business. Regnery was president of Regnery Publishing from 1986 to 2003. In 1993, he sold Regnery Publishing to [[Eagle Publishing]] and took a board position at Eagle. (Eagle Publishing was owned by Tom Philips, a Republican donor.) He was also a partner at the [[Washington, D.C.]]-based law firm Keller and Heckman LLP until 2003. {{cite web | title = Alfred S. Regnery, Managing Director, The Paul Revere Project | publisher = Salem Eagle | url = http://www.eaglepub.com/alfred-regnery/ | date = | accessdate = 7 November 2016}} From 2003 to 2012, Regnery was the publisher of ''[[The American Spectator]]''. He was asked to resign by the Board of Directors of the American Spectator Foundation because of editorial differences. Regnery is managing director of the Paul Revere Project for Salem Eagle, a subsidiary of [[Salem Communications]] (which also bought the Regnery imprint) and has served on Salem Eagle's board since 1993. ==Associations== In 1995, Regnery co-founded the Law Enforcement Legal Defense Fund; in 2014, he became chairman of its board, which includes [[Edwin Meese III]], [[J. Kenneth Blackwell]], [[Ron Hosko]], and [[Ken Cuccinelli]] as directors. {{cite web | title = Board of Directors | publisher = Law Enforcement Legal Defense Fund | url = http://www.policedefense.org/board-of-directors/ | date = | accessdate = 8 November 2016}} Currently, he serves as chairman of the Board of Trustees of the [[Intercollegiate Studies Institute]]. {{cite web |url=https://home.isi.org/team |title=Team |publisher= Intercollegiate Studies Institute |date = |accessdate=2 November 2016}} Regnery served as trustee of the [[Philadelphia Society]] from 2011 to 2014. {{cite web |url=http://phillysoc.org/about/past-trustees/ |title=Past Trustees |publisher= Philadelphia Society |date = |accessdate=2 November 2016}} Other associates include the Committee for Western Civilization, [[American Foreign Policy Council]], [[Americans for Tax Reform]], [[Intercollegiate Studies Institute]], [[International Policy Forum]], [[Institute of World Politics]], [http://www.fgfbooks.com/ Fitzgerald Griffin Foundation], [[Leadership Institute]], [http://www.westminster-institute.org/ Westminster Institute], [https://www.whwg.com/ White House Writers Group], [[Hillsdale College]], [[Morton Blackwell]], [[James Lucier Jr.]], [[Robert R. Reilly]], [[Robert Schadler]], and [https://www.heartland.org/about-us/who-we-are/howard-segermark Howard Segermark]. ==Personal life== In 1969, Regnery married Christina S. Sparrow, who died in 2007; they had four children. {{cite news | first = Linton | last = Weeks |title=All Right Already |publisher= Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2002/09/22/all-right-already/46cf0235-e9dc-41c2-b499-8d1d7acab8c0 |date = 22 September 2002 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} {{cite web |title=Alfred Regnery |publisher= NNDB |url=http://www.nndb.com/people/245/000108918/ |date = 22 September 2002 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} {{cite news |title=Christina S. Regnery |publisher= Washington Post |url=https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtontimes/obituary.aspx?n=christina-s-regnery&pid=87511397 |date = 24 April 2007 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} {{cite news |title=Christina S. Regnery |publisher= Washington Times |url=https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtonpost/obituary.aspx?n=christina-s-regnery&pid=87511139 |date = 24 April 2007 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} His cousin is [[William H. Regnery II]], millionaire political activist and donor, founder of the [[National Policy Institute]] (NPI), and employer (through NPI) of [[Richard B. Spencer]].{{Cite news|first1=Aram|last1=Roston|first2=Joel|last2=Anderson|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/aramroston/hes-spent-almost-20-years-funding-the-racist-right-it|title=The Moneyman behind the alt-right|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=October 22, 2017|date=July 23, 2017}} ==Works== * ''U.S. direct marketing law : the complete handbook for managers'' with Richard J. Leighton (1993) * ''Upstream: The Ascendance of American Conservatism'' (2008) * ''Unlikely pilgrim'' (2019) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite web | title = Alfred S. Regnery, Managing Director, The Paul Revere Project | publisher = Salem Eagle | url = http://www.eaglepub.com/alfred-regnery/ | date = | accessdate = 7 November 2016}} * {{cite web | title = Board of Directors | publisher = Law Enforcement Legal Defense Fund | url = http://www.policedefense.org/board-of-directors/ | date = | accessdate = 8 November 2016}} * {{C-SPAN|alfredregnery}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Regnery, Alfred S.}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Beloit College alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin Law School alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:Lawyers from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:American magazine publishers (people)]] [[Category:The American Spectator people]] [[Category:Philadelphia Society members]] [[Category:Conservatism in the United States]] [[Category:Washington, D.C. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{peacock|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person <!-- Infobox officeholder is too general to be useful here --> |name=Augustin Andriamananoro |birth_date={{birth date and age|1968|08|14|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Soamahamanina]], [[Madagascar]] |nationality=[[Malagasy people|Malagasy]] <!-- there is a better term for this nationality --> |office=[[Ministre des Télécommunications, des Postes de la Communication et des Nouvelles Technologies]] }}
'''Augustin Andriamananoro''' (born 14 August 1968 in [[Soamahamanina]], [[Madagascar]]) is a consultant in [[information and communications technology]] and a politician.
==ICT Project Manager == In 1998, Andriamananoro began to gain experience in software engineering and information technologies while in France. Afterwards, he engaged in numerous projects in the Caribbean and Indian Oceans. He was also the project director of Société M & Associés in Guadeloupe in 2002, as well as the General Manager of the Osmosis Business Solutions O.I. group in Antananarivo until 2008. Andriamananoro continues to serve as the General Director to the Malagasy Authority Office for the Study and Regulation of Telecommunications for Madagascar OMERT.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.omert.mg/ |title=ARTEC | Accueil |publisher=Omert.mg |date= |accessdate=2015-06-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920000151/http://www.omert.mg/ |archive-date=20 September 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Andriamananoro was certified by the Galilee Institute of Management in Israël,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.galilcol.ac.il/ |title=Galilee International Management Institute - Home |publisher=Galilcol.ac.il |date= |accessdate=2015-06-06}}</ref> in his capacity as ICT Senior Manager, he was also certified by ''EMPIM''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madagate.com/reportages/photos/4504-texas-usa-augustin-andriamananoro-a-la-nasa.html |title=Texas U.S.A. Augustin Andriamananoro Ă la NASA |publisher=Madagate.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629051157/http://www.madagate.com/reportages/photos/4504-texas-usa-augustin-andriamananoro-a-la-nasa.html |archivedate=2015-06-29 |df= }}</ref> He received his MBA in Telecommunication at the University of Houston in November 2014. [[File:Augustin Andriamananoro.jpg|alt=Public Figure, Former Minister Augustin ANDRIAMANANORO|thumb]]
==Public figure== In November 2009, as Minister of Telecommunications, Post and New Technology, he had the power devolved from the [[President of Madagascar]] to enable the trunk routes on fibre optic cable for the whole of [[East Africa]], a project known as [[LION (cable system)|Project Lion]]. This would link East Africa to East Asia and Europe with submarine internet fibre-optic cables. In March 2010, the Telecom Company [[:fr:TELMA|TELMA]], at that time, laid another [[submarine communications cable|submarine cable]] in the ''Consortium Eassy, which is a project reliant Madagascar with East Africa'', ("Consortium Project to relay Madagascar to the African continent and the wider world").<ref>{{cite web|language=fr |url=http://andriamananoro.net/madagascar-informations-politiques-malagasy-photos-madagascar/a-la-une-de-madagascar/madagate-video-et-affiche/3028-madagascar-backbone-telma-ne-perd-pas-le-nord-avec-20-millions-de-dollars-.html |title=Madagascar Backbone: TELMA ne perd pas le Nord avec 20 millions de dollars |publisher=Andriamananoro.net |date=22 February 2013 |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614030446/http://andriamananoro.net/madagascar-informations-politiques-malagasy-photos-madagascar/a-la-une-de-madagascar/madagate-video-et-affiche/3028-madagascar-backbone-telma-ne-perd-pas-le-nord-avec-20-millions-de-dollars-.html |archivedate=14 June 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|language=fr|url=http://www.telma.mg/images/pdf/backbone_avril09.pdf|work=telma,mg|date=April 2009|title=Le Backbone National Telma: Plus de 3000km fibre optic des 2009|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>
Andriamananoro ensured [[third-party access]] by other telecommunications and infrastructure operators, and established licenses for [[3G]] Internet service, which now cover the entire country of [[Madagascar]]. With over {{convert|6000|km|mi|abbr=on}} of fibre-optic cable, Madagascar became the first country in Africa to be "all fibre", and is the best country in Africa for its telecommunications infrastructure.
He became the Chairman of the Bord to the National Shareholding Company ([http://www.sonapar.mg/ SONAPAR])<ref>{{cite web|language=fr|author= |url=http://www.sonapar.mg/reveal/ |title=SOciété NAtionale de PARticipations &#124 |publisher=Sonapar.mg |date= |accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> from 10 December 2010 to December 2014.
During this time he was the official General Manager of the Authority Office on Regulation of Madagascar Telecommunications, OMERT: roughly equivalent to [[Ofcom]] in the United Kingdom or the U.S. [[Federal Communications Commission]]). He relieved his post in May 2014.
==Politician== Mr Augustin Andriamananoro, a native of [[Soamahamanina]], has been arbitrarily arrested, at a family funeral, by the force elements ([http://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/proces-andriamananoro-verdict-sous-haute-surveillance-a-anosy/ EMMOREG]) on Saturday 10 December 2016. He was imprisoned at the detention centrale of Antanimora, for opposing the illegal occupation of land (land grabs) for gold mining extraction by the Chinese company [http://www.midi-madagasikara.mg/economie/2016/07/19/soamahamanina-suspension-activites-de-lentreprise-jiuxing-mines-s-a-r-l/ Jiuxing Mines SARL], in his home village of Soamahamanina located 68 km west of Antananarivo Madagascar.
" Vox Populi vox dei ". Basically, it was the message that the priest of ECAR Ste Dorothée Soamahamanina passed to the faithful of this place, which had become "historical" as well as to the peers of Augustin Andriamananoro, in this case his family and the members of the [http://www.newsmada.com/2016/12/20/affaire-augustin-a-le-mapar-interpelle-la-communaute-internationale/ MAPAR]. For a mass was organized in this church to support the former Minister of Telecommunications, in particular and for the country in general.
In November 2010, Andriamananoro was promoted to be Head of the Campaign for the [[Malagasy constitutional referendum, 2010|Constitutional Referendum for the Fourth Republic of Madagascar]]). With [[universal suffrage]], he returned more than 75% of the [[Direct election|popular vote]].
In July 2013, he became one of the ''Vice President'' of [http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20161211-madagascar-arrestation-augustin-andriamananoro-ancien-ministre-dirigeant-mapar-andry-rajoelina MAPAR],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G3Qokp5cAIk |title=EMISSION SPECIAL DU 22 JANVIER 2015 Augustin ANDRIAMANANORO |publisher=YouTube.com |date=22 January 2015 |accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> founded by [[Andry Rajoelina]], who had the majority in the Parliament House, of Madagascar since 20 December 2013: [[qua|in his capacity of being]] the state's Vice Président.

{{Underlinked|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Bicycle Technologies International (BTI) | logo = BTI logo oval.jpg | logo_size = 100px | type = Private | foundation = 1993 | location = [[Santa Fe, NM]], United States | key_people = Andrew Wright, Founder Preston Martin, Founder | industry = [[Bicycle industry#Bicycle and component distributors|Bicycle parts and accessories distribution]] | homepage = [http://www.bti-usa.com/ www.bti-usa.com] }}
'''Bicycle Technologies International, Ltd. (BTI)''' is a global distributor of [[bicycle]] components and accessories, based in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]. BTI also participates in the community through [[cycling advocacy]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Quintana |first=Chris |title=A little elbow room for BTI |url=http://www.santafenewmexican.com/business/090412BTI#.UQcEOInjlYh |accessdate=29 January 2013 |newspaper=Santa Fe New Mexican |date=September 4, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> on local and national levels. The company is [[Privately held company|privately held]] and does not disclose its sales figures.
==History== Andrew Wright and [[Preston Martin]] founded Bicycle Technologies International, Ltd. (BTI) in Ashland, OR in 1993. BTI introduced the bicycle industry’s first service center that [[Local bike shop|bike shops]] could send shocks to for tuning and repair, known as [[Shock Treatment]].<ref name="bicycleretailer">{{cite news|last=Staff|first=BRAIN|title=BTI Celebrates 15 Years in Business|url=http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2008/05/13/bti-celebrates-15-years-business#.UQcGzYnjlYg|accessdate=29 January 2013|newspaper=Bicycle Retailer and Industry News|date=2008-05-13}}</ref> BTI’s first wholesale catalog, also released in 1993, was a twenty-four page newsprint flyer with hand-illustrated [[Schematic|schematic drawings]] of every major fork design. From the beginning, BTI fostered a close relationship with early suspension manufacturers, offering a full line of replacement components. Today BTI provides suspension repair, tuning and other authorized warranty center services for 18 major brands.<ref name="bicycleretailer_a">{{cite news|last=BRAIN|first=Staff|title=BTI Grows Factory Service Capabilities|url=http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2011/05/19/bti-grows-factory-service-capabilities#.UQcIfYnjlYg|accessdate=29 January 2013|newspaper=Bicycle Retailer and Industry News|date=2011-05-19}}</ref>
By 1996, the company was looking for a more central location from where they could serve dealers on both coasts. With the help of friends the young company packed up its inventory and relocated to Santa Fe, NM.<ref name="bicycleretailer" />
Over time, BTI expanded its selection with more shop essentials covering every aspect of the modern bicycle. BTI now stocks over 22,000 unique SKUs from nearly 300 brands.<ref name="bicyclenewswire">{{cite web|title=BTI Catalog Now Shipping|url=http://www.bicyclenewswire.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.showreleasemore&id=3258|publisher=Bicycle News Wire|accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref>
===New Facility=== In June 2012, BTI publicly unveiled its plans for a new facility. The company announced plans to make a significant investment in a new 47,500 square foot building that will expand the current warehouse operation and will bring two other facilities back under one roof. New Mexico Gov. [[Susana Martinez]] spoke at the event, praising BTI for creating quality jobs in the state. Santa Fe City Councilwoman Rebecca Wurzberger said BTI was the type of locally grown, green company that Santa Fe wants to attract not only for job creation, but for community building activities as well. She cited BTI's role in organizing the 2012 IMBA World Summit in Santa Fe as an example.<ref>{{cite news|last=Staff|first=BRAIN|title=BTI breaks ground on new distribution center|url=http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2012/07/02/bti-breaks-ground-new-distribution-center#.UQcSeYnjlYg|accessdate=29 January 2013|newspaper=Bicycle Retailer and Industry News|date=2012-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Desk|first=News|title=Bicycle Technologies International Expands In Sante Fe, New Mexico, Doubling Its Workforce|url=http://www.areadevelopment.com/newsItems/7-3-2012/bicycle-technologies-international-expands-santefe-988801.shtml|accessdate=29 January 2013|newspaper=Area Development Online|date=2012-07-03}}</ref>
Situated on a recently purchased plot of land 5 miles from the current warehouse, BTI's new facility will be the anchor tenant for a new master plan employment zone located next to the [[Santa Fe Community College]] and near [[Rancho Viejo, New Mexico|Rancho Viejo]]. Architectural plans for this site have been completed by Dekker/Parich/ Sabatini Architects. Klinger Constructors LLC has been contracted to undertake construction upon BTI’s acquisition of the property.
==Brands== BTI’s high rate of growth is attributed to the company's broad wholesale product selection. BTI inventories components from all three of the largest bicycle drivetrain brands, [[Shimano]], [[SRAM Corporation|SRAM]] and [[Campagnolo]]. BTI also offers a full range of accessories, including computers, lights, pumps, nutrition and apparel.<ref name="bicyclenewswire" />
==Services== BTI’s Factory Service Center is a suspension and disc brake repair service that bike shops send repairs to when they do not have the time, proper tools or training to process repairs in-house. The department takes in forks for repair and tuning - replacing seals and performance tuning the shock for the specific rider and terrain. BTI also performs warranty repair services for several of its top brands.<ref name="bicycleretailer_a" />
==Advocacy== BTI donates funds annually to bicycle interest groups such as Bikes Belong, [[International Mountain Bicycling Association]] and National Bicycle Dealers Association.<ref name="bti-usa">{{cite web|title=Advocacy|url=https://www.bti-usa.com/public/advocacy|publisher=BTI|accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref> BTI staff regularly attend the annual National Bike Summit in Washington, DC with the New Mexico bicycle delegation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bike Summit |url=http://www.bikeleague.org/conferences/summit12/ |accessdate=29 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920221236/http://www.bikeleague.org/conferences/summit12/ |archivedate=20 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> BTI’s in-house advocacy team is also involved in Santa Fe City and County policy making. In 2010 BTI launched Advocacy Roundup<ref name="bti-usa" /> a program that encourages wholesale customers to donate spare change from purchase transactions to a fund designed to promote the work of advocacy organizations. BTI was recognized for its advocacy efforts by the [[League of American Bicyclists]], who awarded the company Gold level status in its Bicycle Friendly Business category.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bicycle Friendly Business / Gold Level |url=http://www.bikeleague.org/programs/bicyclefriendlyamerica/bicyclefriendlybusiness/bfb_bicycle_technologies_international.php |publisher=League of American Cyclists |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523215623/http://www.bikeleague.org/programs/bicyclefriendlyamerica/bicyclefriendlybusiness/bfb_bicycle_technologies_international.php |archivedate=2012-05-23 |df= }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=June 2014}} {{use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{use American English|date=June 2014}} {{infobox organization |name = Boys & Girls Harbor, Inc. |image = AR 2008 Student Photography Disc 1 170.jpg |caption = One East 104th Street, the organization's main building. |alt = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |membership = |headquarters = One East 104th Street (at [[Fifth Avenue]])
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] 10029
United States |founder = [[Anthony Drexel Duke]] |formation = {{start date and age|1937|paren=yes}} |type = [[Educational]] |budget = |purpose = |region_served = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |motto = |website = {{URL|theharbor.org}} }} '''Boys & Girls Harbor, Inc.''' (formerly called '''Boys Harbor''') is an American educational organization, headquartered in the [[Manhattan]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Founded by [[Anthony Drexel Duke]] in 1937, as a sleepaway [[summer camp]] for boys in [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton]], [[New York (state)|New York]],Friend Recalls Young Deans, Ellis Henican, [[Newsday]], 10 Dec 2003: A04. the organization has grown into several programs. The Harbor was one of the first organizations to launch a [[Charter schools in the United States|charter school]] in New York state and has since then created programs that include [[pre-school]], extended day tutoring, [[literacy]] training, [[Substance abuse prevention|substance-abuse prevention]], [[college preparation]], workforce readiness, and a conservatory for the [[performing arts]].[http://www.theharbor.org]. Boys & Girls Harbor, Inc. Three-quarters of the students range from the ages of 6 to 17 and are 56 percent [[African American]], 35 percent [[Latino]], and 9 percent from another heritage. The constituents average a general population of 53 percent male and 47 percent female. Most of the students live in East or Central [[Harlem]] (67 percent), but 17 percent live in [[The Bronx]], 6 percent live in [[Brooklyn]], 5 percent live in [[Queens]], and the remaining 5 percent live elsewhere in the [[New York metropolitan area|tri-state area]]."Fact Sheet" 2009. ==Founder and history== Duke, a member of the [[Duke family]] and a descendant of the [[Biddle family|Biddle]] and [[Drexel family|Drexel families]], attended [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]], a preparatory school in [[Concord, New Hampshire|Concord]], [[New Hampshire]], and in 1941, graduated from [[Princeton University]], in [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]], [[New Jersey]]. Duke started Boys and Girls Harbor in 1937, at the age of 19, as a summer camp for immigrant and disadvantaged boys. Recruiting friends and family as camp counselors, Duke believed that fresh air mixed with discipline and mutual respect would help discover these inner-city boys' talents and potential.Staff (November 2, 2005). [http://www.princeton.edu/~paw/web_exclusives/alumni_spotlight/as110205duke.html "Nonprofit Offers Inner-City Youths What Suburbs Take for Granted"]. [[Princeton University]]. Retrieved June 20, 2014. After three years (1935–1937) of orchestrating and planning this summer program, Duke and fellow St. Paul's friends found a vacant campsite called Duck Island near [[Southampton, New York|Southampton]], New York. Duck Island remained the site of "Boys Harbor" until Duke was commissioned in the [[U.S. Navy]] to fight in [[World War II]] in 1941. The camp reopened in 1947 in [[Connecticut]] at a place called "Lord's Highway"; the camp migrated to several other locations until 1954 when [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton]], New York, became the camp's permanent home. In 1963, Duke acquired a townhouse on East 94th Street in New York City to create a year-round center in the city for the Harbor children. The 1960s through the 1970s were a time of rapid growth for the institution; it upgraded to the former [[Heckscher Building]] at 104th Street and [[Fifth Avenue]] (Boys and Girls Harbor's present-day home) to accommodate the expanding number of programs, participants, and staff. Also, the institution became fully coeducational and extended its mission to performing arts programs, day care for preschoolers, and drug- and alcohol-prevention classes. Since the starting days of Boys & Girls Harbor, Duke dedicated his life to the mission he created back in 1937: "to empower the lives of inner-city young people, helping them overcome adversity as they achieve their creative, intellectual, and economic dreams."Boys & Girls Harbor 1997 Information Packet. His goal of properly educating the youth of America and giving children an opportunity to actively participate in society is still successfully being achieved to this day. "My feeling is that if we're going to preserve our democracy, we can't have so many people falling through the cracks. We've got to give them their desserts, which is not just respect, it's a good education." – Anthony Drexel Duke On April 30, 2014, Duke died of cancer at the age of 95.Vecsey, Taylor K. (April 30, 2014). [http://easthamptonstar.com/Lead-article/2014430/Tony-Duke-Founder-Boys-Harbor-Has-Died "Tony Duke, Founder of Boys Harbor, Has Died"]. ''[[The East Hampton Star]]''. Retrieved June 20, 2014. ==Programs== The Harbor is located at One East 104th Street, and features pre-kindergarten, The Emily N. Carey Harbor Preschool, Harbor K.I.D.S. (ages 5–11) and Harbor T.E.E.N. (ages 12–18) after-school programs, K.I.D.S., T.E.E.N. and Conservatory Summer Programs, and the [[Harbor Conservatory for the Performing Arts]]. ==See also== {{portal|Education|New York City}} * [[Education in New York City]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{URL|theharbor.org}}, the organization's official website {{Coord|40.7929|-73.9519|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boys And Girls Harbor}} [[Category:1937 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Biddle family]] [[Category:Drexel family]] [[Category:Duke family]] [[Category:East Hampton (town), New York]] [[Category:Fifth Avenue]] [[Category:Education in Manhattan]] [[Category:Education in Suffolk County, New York]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1937]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Southampton (town), New York]] [[Category:Summer camps in Connecticut]] [[Category:Summer camps in New York (state)]] [[Category:Upper East Side]]

{{Infobox person | name = Camillo Castiglioni | image = Camillo Castiglioni.jpg | image_size = 100px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1879|10|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Trieste]], [[Austria–Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|12|18|1879|10|22|df=y}} | death_place = [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = Austria | other_names = | known_for = Critical contributions to [[BMW AG]] in its early years; wealthiest man in Central Europe; owned over 170 companies; passionate about [[Aviation]] and the [[Arts]] | education = Business and Tax Law | employer = | occupation = [[Financier]]; [[Industrialist]] | footnotes = }} '''Camillo Castiglioni''' (22 October 1879 – 18 December 1957) was an Italian-Austrian financier and banker, and was the wealthiest man in Central Europe during [[World War I]]. Nicknamed “Austrian [[Hugo Stinnes|Stinnes]]”, he was active in [[aviation]]'s pioneering days and invested in the [[arts]].
==Early life== Castiglioni was born in [[Trieste]], then part of [[Austria-Hungary]], to the chief rabbi. It is not known when Camillo developed his interest in aviation, but it is known that he was passionate about flying. Camillo's education was primarily law, gaining employment as an attorney and legal officer of a bank in [[Padua]], quickly learning international finance and how to manage capital.
He was the son of a rubber maker, so naturally Camillo found work with the Austro-American ''Gummiwarenfabrik AG'' (rubber products) in [[Vienna]] as an Agent for the Kaufmann automobile tire division in [[Constantinople]]. Camillo found great success in this position, demonstrating his abilities to negotiate and structure financial deals. In fact, Camillo was so successful, he was promoted to Director of the export department of the parent company in Vienna.
Around 1901, along with Viktor Silberer and Franz Hinterstoissera Camillo helped to create the Viennese aero club (later Austrian aero club). He eventually was made deputy director, then in 1904 he was appointed to General Director of the company. Through his experience in the rubber and tire production field, Camillo saw the birth of aviation as an industry, going from a ballooning hobby, to makeshift glider craft requiring tires, to fully operational aircraft operated by engines. He met many influential men in his business, and came to realize that aviation sparked not only his passion for flight, but also recognized the tremendous financial opportunity of aviation's potential as an industry.
In order to draw from the arising enthusiasm for airplanes and ballooning, as well as to take advantage of the lucrative business the hobby generated, Camillo established one of his first companies, ''[[Luft-Fahrzeug-Gesellschaft|Luftfahrzeug-Gesellschaft]]'', in 1907. Being a pure commercial firm – it acquired the Etrich balloon patents and sold balloon fliers in Austria Hungary. There were many contests that these inspired balloon drivers entered, and Camillo was no different- he bought his own balloon and successfully took his balloon driver examination on 24 August 1909.
==Aviation financing== During the First World War, became one of the richest and most influential financiers in Central Europe.
The first major investor in the series production of aircraft. 1914 Purchased the German aircraft company [[Hansa- und Brandenburgische Flugzeugwerke]], which employed [[Ernst Heinkel]] as its chief designer. Acquired a majority holding in [[Austro-Daimler]] with its chief designers [[Puch]] and [[Porsche]]. Press "Czar" and sponsor of the arts (financed [[Max Reinhardt]] and helped him to organize the [[Salzburg Festival]]). After a series of setbacks, his financial empire broke up in 1926. He retired to [[Switzerland]], then to [[Milan]] where he set up a private bank and once again amassed a considerable fortune. After the Second World War, negotiated a large US loan for his friend [[Josip Broz Tito]] in [[Yugoslavia]]. When Tito refused to pay his commission, Castiglioni succeeded in getting Yugoslavian assets in Italy worth millions sequestered. 1916 Awarded the [[Franz Joseph Order]] with ribbon on the [[Military Service Cross]] for his services to aviation 1918 with the [[St-Georges Order]] for his achievements in the war material production.
Castiglioni became rich in ventures during the period of inflation, acquiring a majority interest in ''[[Alpine Montan AG]]''. The Austrian aviation company ''[[Österreichische Luftfahrtsgesellschaft]]'' was founded by him.
==BMW influence== Castiglioni significantly influenced the development of BMW AG in its early years. The granting of a license agreement by Austro-Daimler to the Rapp-Werke in 1917 was partly attributable to Castiglioni. 1918 At Castiglioni's insistence the Wiener Bankverein (Vienna) acquired the majority of BMW's share capital. 1922 Castiglioni purchased all the equipment relating to engine construction, the associated know-how and the rights to the name "Bayerische Motoren Werke AG" from the BMW AG, which was renamed Süddeutsche Bremse AG. Castiglioni in turn renamed the Bayerische Flugzeugwerke to BMW AG and allowed the renamed company to continue production at the BFW plant. From the establishment of BMW AG until November 9, 1922 and then from 1924 to 1929, he was a member of the Supervisory Board and President of BMW AG. 1928 Deputy Chairman of the Supervisory Board.
His was one of the voices that urged BMW in 1928 to purchase the Eisenach Automobilwerke. Due to financial difficulties in 1929 he was obliged to surrender his holding of BMW shares to a consortium of banks ([[Deutsche Bank]], [[Disconto-Gesellschaft|Disconto]], [[Bankhaus Hagen]] etc.).
A consortium led by the Deutsche Bank and the Diskonto-Gesellschaft purchased the BMW shares previously held by Camillo Castiglioni, who was facing problems of liquidity.
==Failed speculation and bankruptcy== In February 1924, Castiglioni partnered with [[Fritz Mannheimer]], and later other influential bankers to speculate on the [[devaluation]] of the [[French franc]]. They [[Short (finance)|shorted]] hundreds of millions of franc, eventually causing the franc to drop almost 40% in less than a month. By the beginning of March 1924, one [[United States dollar]] was worth 28 francs. Then, however, investment bank [[Lazard]], on the behalf of [[Banque de France]] and powered by [[J.P. Morgan & Co.]],<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Morgan Syndicate Lends $100,000,000 To Bank of France |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1924/03/13/archives/morgan-syndicate-lends-100000000-to-bank-of-france-credit-here.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |publisher= |date=1924-03-13 |accessdate= }}</ref> bought immense amounts of francs, causing the franc to rise again, to 15 franc per dollar. Castiglioni, Mannheimer and their partners lost millions.
In September 1924, the Austrian [[Depositenbank]], of which Castiglioni had been president, collapsed.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Austria Is Shaken by Big Bank Crash |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1924/09/30/archives/austria-is-shaken-by-big-bank-crash-castiglioni-richest-man-in-the.html |work=The New York Times |publisher= |date=1924-09-30 |accessdate= }}</ref> A warrant for his arrest on a charge of fraud was issued, but Castiglioni had been taken care to be in Italy when the crash came. The Austrian State said that if he deposited $4,200,000 (${{Inflation|US|4200000|1924}} in present-day value), he could return unmolested.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Gone |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,736356,00.html |work=[[Time Magazine]] |publisher= |date=1924-10-06 |accessdate= }}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Castiglioni built up a large art collection and a theatre in [[Vienna]]. He was the richest man in Central Europe and much beloved by the Viennese whom he assisted financially on Sundays and odd occasions. He was also a patron of the arts and for some time supported the famed producer [[Max Reinhardt]], for whom he built a theater. So fond was he of appearing in the public limelight that he lived with all the pomp and ceremony of royalty, even traveling in the Kaiser Karl's private parlor car, which he bought.
Because of his famous banking activities, his life was documented in a 1988 movie on television titled ''[[Camillo Castiglioni oder die Moral der Haifische]]'' (in English: ''Camillo Castiglioni, or the morality of sharks''), directed by [[Peter Patzak]].

[[File:CSUCom.jpg|250px|thumbnail| School of Communication at CSU with the Rhodes Tower in background]][[File:St. Vincents.jpg|250px|thumbnail|St.Vincent's Charity Medical Center at dusk]][[File:CCCOLLEGE.jpg|250px|thumbnail|Cuyahoga Community College Metropolitan Campus]] The '''''Campus District''''' is a major downtown [[Cleveland, Ohio]] neighborhood that includes the campuses of [[Cleveland State University]], St. Vincent Charity Medical Center,<ref>https://www.stvincentcharity.com/ St. Vincent Charity Medical Center</ref> and [[Cuyahoga Community College]].<ref>http://campusdistrict.org/ Retrieved on 2015-08-18</ref> The District spans from East 17th Street to East 30th Street, and from Lake Erie in the north to Orange Avenue in the south. Cleveland State University (CSU) is positioned centrally within the district, located along Euclid Avenue. Cuyahoga Community College (Tri-C) is located in the southern portion of the district, at East 30th and Community College Avenue and St. Vincent Charity Medical Center is located along East 22nd Street, south of Interstate 90.
The District is also home to Northeast Ohio Medical University at Cleveland State University, The Care Alliance Central Neighborhood Clinic, and the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum]] Archives. In addition, the [[Ohio Technical College]] campus sits just to the north of the district.
The Main Avenues of the district are Superior, Payne, Chester, Euclid, Carnegie, East 22nd Street, Community College, and East 30th Street.
==See also== [[List of colleges and universities in Ohio]]

{{Infobox building |name = Coleman A. Young Municipal Center |image = CAYMC.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = The Coleman A. Young Municipal Center, looking southeast from West Larned Street. |location = 2 Woodward Avenue
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] |coordinates = |status = Completed |start_date = 1951 |completion_date = 1954 |opening = |building_type = [[City Hall]] |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|318|ft|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 20 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = |architect = Harley, Ellington & Day |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = |owner = |management = Detroit-Wayne Joint Building Authority |references = }} The '''Coleman A. Young Municipal Center''' is a government office building and courthouse located at 2 Woodward Avenue in [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]] [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Originally called the '''City-County Building''', it was renamed for the former [[Mayor of Detroit|Detroit Mayor]] [[Coleman A. Young]], shortly after his death in 1997. It serves as the [[Government of Detroit|City of Detroit government]] headquarters. The Coleman A. Young Municipal Center houses offices, courtrooms, and meeting rooms. The class-A office building stands near the [[Renaissance Center]], [[Hart Plaza]], [[One Detroit Center]], [[Courtyard by Marriott - Downtown Detroit]], and the [[Millender Center]]. ==Architecture== [[File:Detroit December 2015 41 (Coleman A. Young Municipal Center).jpg|thumb|left|The Coleman A. Young Municipal Center in December 2015]] The modernist [[International style (architecture)|International-style]] building was designed by the architectural firm of Harley, Ellington and Day. Construction began on the [[list of tallest buildings in Detroit|skyscraper]] in 1951 and was completed in 1954. It is 20 floors tall, and including the basement has 21 total floors. Three sides of the building's exterior are faced with white Vermont [[marble]] with black marble [[spandrel]] panels beneath the windows of the Courts Tower to emphasize the building's vertical lines.{{Cite book | author=Meyer, Katherine Mattingly and Martin C.P. McElroy with Introduction by W. Hawkins Ferry, Hon A.I.A.| title=Detroit Architecture A.I.A. Guide Revised Edition | year= 1980| publisher= Wayne State University Press| isbn = 0-8143-1651-4}} The verticality of the tower section, with its white marble-clad piers and dark spandrels, offers a distinct contrast with the 14-story Administration Tower office section, in which horizontal lines are emphasized. The brick of the Randolph Street facade was not covered with marble to allow for a more economical future expansion. ===Towers=== ;Administration Tower The 14-story portion of this complex is called the Administration Tower and is {{convert|197|ft|abbr=on}} tall, from the ground to the [[mechanical floor|mechanical penthouse roof parapet]]. The Administration Tower holds offices for the City of Detroit and Wayne County, as well as doctor clinics, laboratories, a municipal library, and the City Council [[auditorium]] chambers on the 13th floor. ;Courts Tower The 20-story portion of this complex is called the Courts Tower and is {{convert|318|ft|abbr=on}} tall. It contains office space on floors 1 through 8, and [[courtroom]]s, judges chambers, and [[jury room]]s on floors 9 through 19, with the 20th floor housing the building's [[mechanical floor|mechanical equipment]]. A marble wall element rises {{convert|43.5|ft|m}} high stands {{convert|17|ft|m}} west of the Courts Tower, and is connected to the tower by a canopy that forms the Woodward Avenue entrance. [[Bas relief]]s of the Detroit and Wayne County seals are carved in the wall, along with a quote from the Bible ([[2 Corinthians]] 3:17) ''Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty''. [[File:The Spirit of Detroit.JPG|thumb|300px|"[[The Spirit of Detroit]]" by sculptor [[Marshall Fredericks]], at the municipal center.]] ===Statue=== "[[The Spirit of Detroit]]," a {{convert|25|ft|m}} tall bronze statue by sculptor [[Marshall Fredericks]], is located at the Courts Tower's marble wall element. As one of Detroit's most easily identifiable landmarks, a sketch of the statue appears as the central element of most of the logos of Detroit's city departments and services. When Detroit sports teams (the Red Wings, Pistons and Tigers) have been in contention for their league's championship, the statue has traditionally been outfitted with a huge version of the appropriate team's jersey. ===Skyway=== An enclosed [[skyway]] over Randolph Street connects to the [[Millender Center]], [[Courtyard by Marriott - Downtown Detroit]], and the [[Renaissance Center]] as a sort of "enclosed city within a city". Entrance from the walkway to the third-floor level requires a security pass, and persons without a pass must return to the main floor entrance. ==Operations== The Coleman A. Young Municipal Center is operated by the Detroit-Wayne Joint Building Authority, which was created in 1948 by the [[Michigan Legislature]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dwjba.com/propertyprofile.html|title=Property Profile|publisher=dwjba.com|accessdate=2010-10-15}} The building contains a [[library]], a [[courthouse]], and the [[city hall]]. When it opened, the City-County Building replaced both the historic [[Detroit City Hall]] and [[Wayne County Building]]. Many [[Wayne County, Michigan|Wayne County]] offices have since moved to the nearby [[Guardian Building]] which now serves as the county's headquarters. The offices of the Wayne County Clerk remain in the building as does one division of the Wayne County (Third Judicial) Circuit Court, Circuit Court Administrative Offices and the Wayne County Probate Court. On June 28, 2008, the Coleman A. Young Municipal Center was struck by [[lightning]] during a series of intense [[thunderstorm]]s, and caused a [[transformer]] fire within the building. It re-opened for service on July 9, 2008. The smoke and fire damage is easily visible across the river, in [[Windsor, Ontario]], where many windows have been removed, or have shattered. ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Cite book |author1=Hill, Eric J. |author2=John Gallagher | title= AIA Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture| year=2002 | publisher= Wayne State University Press | isbn=0-8143-3120-3}} *{{Cite book | author= Sharoff, Robert | title=American City: Detroit Architecture| publisher=Wayne State University Press| year=2005| isbn=0-8143-3270-6| authorlink= Robert Sharoff}} {{commons category|Coleman A. Young Municipal Center}} ==External links== {{Portal|Metro Detroit}} * [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=118533 Coleman A. Young Municipal Center at Emporis.com] * [http://www.skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=1999 SkyscraperPage.com's Profile on the Coleman A. Young Municipal Center] {{Coord|42.32947|-83.04416|type:landmark_region:US-MI|display=title}} {{Downtown Detroit}} {{Architecture of metropolitan Detroit}} {{Detroit}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Detroit]] [[Category:Downtown Detroit|Young Municipal Center]] [[Category:City and town halls in Michigan|Young Municipal Center]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Detroit|Young Municipal Center]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1954]] [[Category:International style architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Michigan]]

{{merge|customer retention|date=August 2018}} '''Customer attrition''', also known as '''customer churn''', '''customer turnover''', or '''customer defection''', is the loss of clients or customers.
[[Bank]]s, telephone service companies, [[Internet service provider]]s, [[pay TV]] companies, [[insurance]] firms, and alarm monitoring services, often use customer attrition analysis and customer attrition rates as one of their key business [[Metric (mathematics)|metrics]] (along with [[cash flow]], [[EBITDA]], etc.) because the cost of retaining an existing customer is far less than acquiring a new one.<ref>[http://hbr.org/1990/09/zero-defections-quality-comes-to-services/ar/1 ''Zero Defections: Quality comes to service.''], Reichheld & Sasser. Harvard Business review. 1990.</ref> Companies from these sectors often have [[customer service]] branches which attempt to win back defecting clients, because recovered long-term customers can be worth much more to a company than newly recruited clients.
Companies usually make a distinction between '''voluntary churn''' and '''involuntary churn'''. Voluntary churn occurs due to a decision by the customer to switch to another company or service provider, involuntary churn occurs due to circumstances such as a customer's relocation to a long-term care facility, death, or the relocation to a distant location. In most applications, involuntary reasons for churn are excluded from the analytical models. Analysts tend to concentrate on voluntary churn, because it typically occurs due to factors of the company-customer relationship which companies control, such as how billing interactions are handled or how after-sales help is provided.
When companies are measuring their customer turnover, they typically make the distinction between '''gross attrition''' and '''net attrition'''. Gross attrition is the loss of existing customers and their associated [[recurring revenue]] for contracted goods or services during a particular period. Net attrition is gross attrition plus the addition or recruitment of similar customers at the original location. Financial institutions often track and measure attrition using a weighted calculation called '''Recurring Monthly Revenue''' (or '''RMR'''). In the 2000s, there are also a number of [[business intelligence]] software programs which can [[data mining|mine databases]] of customer information and analyze the factors that are associated with customer attrition, such as dissatisfaction with service or technical support, billing disputes, or a disagreement over company policies. More sophisticated [[predictive analytics]] software use churn prediction models that predict customer churn by assessing their propensity of risk to churn. Since these models generate a small prioritized list of potential defectors, they are effective at focusing [[customer retention]] marketing programs on the subset of the customer base who are most vulnerable to churn.
==Retail services applications== [[Financial services]] such as banking and insurance use applications of [[predictive analytics]] for churn modeling, because customer retention is an essential part of most financial services' [[business model]]s. Other sectors have also discovered the power of predictive analytics, including [[retail]]ing, [[telecommunications]] and pay-TV operators. One of the main objectives of modeling customer churn is to determine the causal factors, so that the company can try to prevent the attrition from happening in the future. Some companies want to prevent their ''good'' customers from deteriorating (e.g., by falling behind in their payments) and becoming less profitable customers, so they introduced the notion of '''partial customer churn'''.
Customer attrition merits special attention by mobile telecom service providers worldwide. This is due to the low barriers to switching to a competing service provider especially with the advent of Mobile Number Portability (MNP) in several countries. This allows customers to switch to another provider while preserving their phone numbers. While mature markets with high teledensity (phone market penetration) have [[churn rate]]s ranging from 1% to 2% per month, high growth developing markets such as India and China are experiencing churn rates between 3% to 4% per month. By deploying new technologies such churn prediction models coupled with effective retention programs, customer attrition could be better managed to stem the significant revenue loss from defecting customers.
Customer attrition is a major concern for US and Canadian banks, because they have much higher churn rates than banks in Western Europe. US and Canadian banks with the lowest churn rates have achieved customer turnover rates as low as 12% per year, by using tactics such as free checking accounts, [[online banking]] and bill payment, and improved customer service. However, once banks can improve their churn rates by improving customer service, they can reach a point beyond which further customer service will not improve retention; other tactics or approaches need to be explored.
Churn or Customer attrition is often used as an indicator of customer satisfaction. However the churn rate can be kept artificially low by making it difficult for the customers to resiliate their services. This can include ignoring resiliations requests, implementing lengthy and complicated resiliation procedures to follow through by an average consumer and various other barriers to resiliation. Thus, churn can improve while customer satisfaction deteriorates. This practice is short sighted and will backfire. However, it was shown{{By whom|date=October 2017}} to be common in telephone companies and among internet providers.
==Research== Scholars have studied customer attrition at European financial services companies, and investigated the predictors of churn and how the use of [[customer relationship management]] (CRM) approaches can impact churn rates. Several studies combine several different types of predictors to develop a churn model. This model can take [[Demography|demographic characteristics]], environmental changes, and other factors into account.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Customer Attrition Analysis For Financial Services Using Proportional Hazard Models | citeseerx = 10.1.1.62.8919 | author1 = Van Den Poel | author2 = Lariviére | journal = European Journal of Operational Research | year = 2004 | doi = 10.1016/s0377-2217(03)00069-9 | volume=157 | pages=196–217}}</ref>
Research on customer attrition data modeling may provide businesses with several tools for enhancing customer retention. Using data mining and software, one may apply statistical methods to develop nonlinear attrition causation models. One researcher notes that "...retaining existing customers is more profitable than acquiring new customers due primarily to savings on acquisition costs, the higher volume of service consumption, and customer referrals." The argument is that to build an "...effective customer retention program," managers have to come to an understanding of "...why customers leave" and "...identify the customers with high risk of leaving" by accurately predicting customer attrition.<ref>[http://www.lib.unb.ca/Texts/JCIM/bin/get.cgi?directory=vol6_1/&filename=li.html ''Applying and evaluating models to predict customer attrition using data mining techniques''], Tom Au, et al. Journal of Comparative International Management. 1 June 2003</ref>
==Prediction== In the [[business]] context, "churn" refers both to customers' migration and to their loss of value. So, "churn rate" refers, on the one hand, to the percentage of customers who end their relation with the organization, or, on the other hand, to the customers who still receive their services, but not as much or not as often as they used to. Current organizations face therefore a huge challenge: to be able to anticipate to customers’ abandon in order to retain them on time, reducing this way costs and risks and gaining efficiency and competitivity. There are in the market advanced analytics tools and applications, especially designed to analyze in depth the enormous amount of data inside the organizations, and to make predictions based on the information obtained from analyzing and exploring those data. They aim to put at the service of [[marketing]] departments and agencies –and of all business users- the necessary weapons to: * Detect soon which customers are about to abandon and to know them in depth, answering to questions such as: Who are they? or How do they behave? * Know the real value of the potential loss of those customers, with the aim of establishing priorities and distributing business efforts and resources efficiently, optimizing resources and maximizing the value of the current customers’ portfolio. * Put into practice personalized retention plans in order to reduce or avoid their migration, increasing the capability to react and anticipating to possible non-predicted fugues.
==Reduction== There are organizations that have developed international standards regarding recognition and sharing of global best practice in [[customer service]] in order to reduce customer attrition. [[The International Customer Service Institute]] has developed The International Customer Service Standard to strategically align organizations so they focus on delivering excellence in customer service, whilst at the same time providing recognition of success through a 3rd Party registration scheme.
==Management== Not all customer attrition is bad. For many firms, it is useful and desirable that unprofitable customers should churn away. This is known as customer divestment of unprofitable customers.<ref>Ka‐shing Woo, Henry K.Y. Fock, (2004) Retaining and divesting customers: an exploratory study of right customers, “at‐risk” right customers, and wrong customers. ''Journal of Services Marketing, 18'', 187-197.</ref> However, simply because a customer is unprofitable does not mean that the customer should be divested, because there are strategic reasons for retaining unprofitable customers.
==See also== * [[Churn rate]] * [[Customer retention]]
==References== <references />
==Further reading== * Buckinx Wouter, Dirk Van den Poel (2005), "[http://econpapers.repec.org/paper/rugrugwps/03_2F178.htm Customer Base Analysis: Partial Defection of Behaviorally-Loyal Clients in a Non-Contractual FMCG Retail Setting]", ''European Journal of Operational Research'', 164 (1), 252–268. * Burez Jonathan, Dirk Van den Poel (2006), "[http://econpapers.repec.org/paper/rugrugwps/05_2F348.htm CRM at a Pay-TV Company: Using Analytical Models to Reduce Customer Attrition by Targeted Marketing for Subscription Services]," ''Expert Systems with Applications'', 32 (2), 277–288. * Prinzie Anita, Dirk Van den Poel (2005), “[http://econpapers.repec.org/paper/rugrugwps/05_2F292.htm Incorporating sequential information into traditional classification models by using an element/position-sensitive SAM]”, ''Decision Support Systems'', 42 (2), 508–526. * Pohl Stefan (2007), Zeitraumbezogene Stornomodellierung in der Kraftfahrtversicherung, Zeitschrift für Versicherungswesen (ZfV)'', 59 (11), 361–368.
